image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe is facing the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time. Meanwhile, US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: RBA boss says it's 'too early to declare victory' against inflation but 'the worst is over'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're nearing the end of the hearing and Philip Lowe has started to discuss his "popularity" (or lack thereof) depending on what's happening with the interest rate cycle. "We've raised interest rates in election campaigns, we've raised interest rates when it hasn't been popular with the political class," he said. "I hope that people understand that the decisions are taken completely independently. I've been involved in the interest rate setting process for a number of decades, and no politician has indirectly or directly put pressure on the bank during that period. "It's one of the very positive things about about Australia is that the political class do not put pressure on the central bank. And we take our decisions completely independently of the political noise. "I know what we do often is unpopular, and sometimes what I say is unpopular, but that hasn't diminished our resolve to do the right thing. "I hope Australians understand that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe acknowledges what he says can be 'unpopular'

children.content: We're nearing the end of the hearing and Philip Lowe has started to discuss his "popularity" (or lack thereof) depending on what's happening with the interest rate cycle.
"We've raised interest rates in election campaigns, we've raised interest rates when it hasn't been popular with the political class," he said.

"I hope that people understand that the decisions are taken completely independently. I've been involved in the interest rate setting process for a number of decades, and no politician has indirectly or directly put pressure on the bank during that period.

"It's one of the very positive things about about Australia is that the political class do not put pressure on the central bank. And we take our decisions completely independently of the political noise.
"I know what we do often is unpopular, and sometimes what I say is unpopular, but that hasn't diminished our resolve to do the right thing.
"I hope Australians understand that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe was also asked if he plans on being a "Tony Abbott" or "Julia Gillard" when it comes to his public presence after leaving the RBA next month. "I don't think I'll be like either," he replied. "My main objective is see if I get my golf handicap in the single digits. "I don't plan to be a public commentator whose job is being a commentator."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe's post-RBA plans? The golf course, not professional commentator

children.content: Philip Lowe was also asked if he plans on being a "Tony Abbott" or "Julia Gillard" when it comes to his public presence after leaving the RBA next month.
"I don't think I'll be like either," he replied.
"My main objective is see if I get my golf handicap in the single digits.
"I don't plan to be a public commentator whose job is being a commentator."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe was asked if he had any regrets during his time as RBA governor. Here's his full response to the question: "I wish I had understood the implications of the pandemic a bit more. The period in early 2020 was incredibly scary, nd our mindset was to provide maximum support medical insurance to protect against the worst possible outcome, and we did that. "It turned out we provided too much support and perhaps too much insurance and that's contributed to inflation problems now. "We didn't fully understand the nature of the pandemic and how long it would last and what the implications would be for the economy. "So I wish in retrospect that we'd been able to understand that in more detail, and if we would have, if we had a better understanding, then we would have responded differently. "I remember being too being told that the unemployment rate was going to 15%, the vaccine wouldn't be for five years, maybe it wasn't effective, people could be forced to stay at home for years — it was incredibly scary and we responded with maximum insurance. "It turned out the scientists did a much better job than anyone thought. We recovered quickly, we all got vaccinated, the vaccine worked and we back to pre-pandemic days. "I wish I understood that and we would have had a different policy response. So that's my biggest regret, that I didn't understand that better."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I wish I had understood the implications of the pandemic,' Lowe says

children.content: Philip Lowe was asked if he had
any regrets
during his time as RBA governor.
Here's his full response to the question:

"I wish I had understood the implications of the pandemic a bit more. The period in early 2020 was incredibly scary, nd our mindset was to provide maximum support medical insurance to protect against the worst possible outcome, and we did that.
"It turned out
we provided too much support and perhaps too much insurance and that's contributed to inflation problems now
"We didn't fully understand the nature of the pandemic and how long it would last and
what the implications would be for the economy
"So I wish in retrospect that we'd been able to understand that in more detail, and if we would have, if we had a better understanding, then we would have responded differently.

"I remember being too being told that the unemployment rate was going to 15%, the vaccine wouldn't be for five years, maybe it wasn't effective, people could be forced to stay at home for years — it was incredibly scary and
we responded with maximum insurance
"It turned out the scientists did a much better job than anyone thought. We recovered quickly, we all got vaccinated, the vaccine worked and we back to pre-pandemic days.
"I wish I understood that and we would have had a different policy response. So that's my biggest regret, that I didn't understand that better."

title.children: 'A disaster waiting to happen': Cars queue for up to 3km to exit this freeway at peak hour

image.altText: A Spanish player dribbles the ball while being defended against by a Dutch opponent at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals kick off with European powerhouses Spain and Netherlands meeting in Wellington. Later, heavyweights Japan and Sweden meet at Eden Park in Auckland. Follow live.

title.children: Spain hits post twice and has goal ruled out for offside in FIFA World Cup quarterfinal against Netherlands in Wellington

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Even scoreline, but not an even half. The Spanish were well and truly on top, and had the ball in the net on one occasion, only for it to be ruled offside. 61% possession for Spain, 12 shots to 1, 23 touches in the opposition box to 3 - the stats speak for themselves. Netherland goalkeeper Daphne van Domselaar has been brilliant. The good news for the Dutch, it's 0-0. They have been dominated, but have not looked completely overwhelmed. A chance to regroup and see what they can offer in the second half. One thing I'd like to see a bit more from Spain is Bonmati in attacking positions. She's been running the game from deep as usual, but we also know she's very dangerous in the box.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Spain 0 - 0 Netherlands

children.content: Even scoreline, but not an even half. The Spanish were well and truly on top, and had the ball in the net on one occasion, only for it to be ruled offside.
(Getty)
61% possession for Spain, 12 shots to 1, 23 touches in the opposition box to 3 - the stats speak for themselves.
Netherland goalkeeper Daphne van Domselaar has been brilliant.
The good news for the Dutch, it's 0-0. They have been dominated, but have not looked completely overwhelmed. A chance to regroup and see what they can offer in the second half.
One thing I'd like to see a bit more from Spain is Bonmati in attacking positions. She's been running the game from deep as usual, but we also know she's very dangerous in the box.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Spain vs Netherlands quarterfinal is underway!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Donald Trump has appealed against a judge's dismissal of his claim that the writer E. Jean Carroll defamed him by accusing him of rape, after a jury awarded her $US5 million for defamation and sexual abuse but not rape. The former president has asked the federal appeals court in Manhattan to overturn an August 7 decision by US District Judge Lewis Kaplan that also rejected some of his defences in a second defamation lawsuit by Ms Carroll. Both cases stemmed from Mr Trump's denials that he raped Carroll in a Bergdorf Goodman department store dressing room in Manhattan in the mid-1990s. A trial in the second lawsuit is scheduled for January 15, 2024, but Mr Trump wants it put on hold during his separate appeal against Judge Kaplan's June 29 refusal to dismiss it. Ms Carroll's lawyers opposed that request, saying she had waited long enough, and the public would be "poorly served" by granting Mr Trump an "effectively indefinite delay".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump appeals against dismissal of defamation claim against E. Jean Carroll

featuredLink.title: Trump appeals against judge's dismissal of defamation claim against E. Jean Carroll

children.content: Donald Trump has appealed against a judge's dismissal of his claim that the writer E. Jean Carroll defamed him by accusing him of rape, after a jury awarded her
$US5 million
for defamation and sexual abuse but not rape.

The former president has asked the federal appeals court in Manhattan to overturn an August 7 decision by US District Judge Lewis Kaplan that also rejected some of his defences in a second defamation lawsuit by Ms Carroll.
Both cases stemmed from Mr Trump's denials that he raped Carroll in a Bergdorf Goodman department store dressing room in Manhattan in the mid-1990s.
A trial in the second lawsuit is scheduled for January 15, 2024, but Mr Trump wants it put on hold during his separate appeal against Judge Kaplan's June 29 refusal to dismiss it.
Ms Carroll's lawyers opposed that request, saying she had waited long enough, and the public would be "poorly served" by granting Mr Trump an "effectively indefinite delay".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A magnitude 6.1 earthquake has struck the coast of Hokkaido in Japan. According to Geoscience Australia's website the earthquake hit at 10:14 AEST. The quake's epicentre was 53 km below the Earth's surface. Over in New Zealand, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake at the top of its south island was felt in Wellington. The earthquake's epicentre was 75 kilometres north of French Pass.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 6.1  magnitude earthquake hits coast of Japan and a  5.6 earthquake is felt in NZ

props.alt: A red dot off the coast of japan on map

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Russia has launched its first Moon-landing spacecraft in 47 years, in a bid to be the first power to make a soft landing on the lunar south pole, a region believed to hold coveted pockets of water ice. A Soyuz 2.1v rocket carrying the Luna-25 craft blasted off from the Vostochny cosmodrome, 5,550km east of Moscow, at 2:11am Moscow time. Here's the moment of the launch: The lander is due to touch down on the Moon on August 23, Russia's space agency says. The Russian lunar mission, the first since 1976, is racing against India, which sent up its Chandrayaan-3 lunar lander last month, and more broadly with the United States and China.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Russia just launched its first Moon mission in 47 years
